title:
Evaluating S-Band Interference: Impact of Satellite Systems on
  Terrestrial Networks
authors: Lingrui Zhang, Zheng Li and Sheng Yang
abstract:
The co-existence of terrestrial and non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) is
essential for achieving global coverage in sixth-generation cellular networks.
Due to increasing spectrum demand, there is discussion in the world level to
share some frequencies used in terrestrial Networks (TNs) with NTNs, resulting
in co-channel interference and performance degradation. This paper analyzes the
interference caused by satellite networks on TN in the S-band. We examined the
transmission mechanisms of satellite signals and conducted simulations to
evaluate interference intensity across varying slant ranges. Our findings
indicate that the angle between the user equipment direction and the
sub-satellite point direction from the beam center significantly impacts the
interference level.
subjects: Electrical Engineering and Systems Science/Signal Processing
